text.p: These are the leading stories in the Beirut press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-Lebanese police shot dead a Palestinian accused of belonging to a gang charged with forging revenue stamps and selling for private gain genuine stamps supplied by a finance ministry official
--Foreign exchange reserves rose by $153.45 million in the first half of November.
-President Hrawi: Let us call a war on corruption and slander those who cover it up.
-The new government to issue policy statement tomorrow.
-Foreign Minister Bouez discussed with Prime Minister Hariri preparations for the December 16 meeting of the international consultative group in Washington.
The group, which will assist Lebanon in its reconstruction programme, was formed under an April ceasefire understanding which ended 17 days of Israeli onslaught on the country.

-Some 215 Arab bankers arrived in Beirut to participate in a two-day conference on the role of banks in economic reform and reconstruction in the Arab world. The conference is organised by Union of Arab Banks.
-Critics of Prime Minister Hariri made demands for economic changes at a mass meeting on Friday night.
-Lebanon and Germany denied reports that security officials were tracing from Germany missing Israeli airman Ron Arad who was shot down over Lebanon in 1986.
